comments.body: Tiny tiny nitpick but `nonEmpty` now negates `exists` twice. Maybe we should define `nonEmpty` as `exists(fa)(Function.const(true))` and then `isEmpty` as `!nonEmpty` WDYT? :)

Actually I started from that :), but then I changed it as I had the impression it was reading better in my head (not exists instead of not non empty). But I don't really love my version either, as you said double negates, and even if it's simple logic, that makes reasoning convoluted and unnatural. I'm happy to change it ðŸ‘.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +20,24 @@  def isEmpty[A](fa: F[A]): Boolean =
    !nonEmpty(fa)

  def nonEmpty[A](fa: F[A]): Boolean =
    exists(fa)(Function.const(true))

comments.body: This can be implemented with foldMap (map to true, do the commutative â€œorâ€ monoid

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +18,22 @@    * Returns true if there are no elements. Otherwise false.
    */
  def isEmpty[A](fa: F[A]): Boolean =
    exists(fa)(Function.const(true))

comments.body: This can be implemented with unorderedFoldMap

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +29,33 @@    * If there are no elements, the result is `false`.
    */
  def exists[A](fa: F[A])(p: A => Boolean): Boolean =
    unorderedFoldMap(fa)(a => Eval.later(p(a)))(UnorderedFoldable.commutativeMonoidEval(UnorderedFoldable.orMonoid))
      .value

comments.body: This can be implemented with foldMap using and monoid.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +38,42 @@    * If there are no elements, the result is `true`.
    */
  def forall[A](fa: F[A])(p: A => Boolean): Boolean =
    unorderedFoldMap(fa)(a => Eval.later(p(a)))(UnorderedFoldable.commutativeMonoidEval(UnorderedFoldable.andMonoid))
      .value
